thread.title: Rinaldo avoids suspension for hit on Couturier | Hockey
thread.title_full: Rinaldo avoids suspension for hit on Couturier | Hockey | ArcaMax Publishing

author: arcamax.com
title: Rinaldo avoids suspension for hit on Couturier | Hockey
text:
As the Flyers prepare to host the New York Rangers on Saturday night, there is uncertainty surrounding their lineup because of injuries to forwards Sean Couturier and Brayden Schenn.
Both are listed as day-to-day, according to general manager Ron Hextall.
Couturier may have suffered a concussion Wednesday when he was pounded to the ice by a high check to the head by Boston's Zac Rinaldo, an ex-Flyer playing his first game against his former teammates.
Surprisingly, Rinaldo escaped a suspension on Thursday. He was suspended three times with the Flyers, totaling 14 games.
The NHL's department of player safety, in a video it released Thursday, acknowledged Couturier's head was struck, "but it was not the main point of contact" and it said Rinaldo did not launch into the center.
Rinaldo was given a five-minute charging penalty and a game misconduct. The puck was not in the area when Rinaldo charged into Couturier by the boards, and his head snapped back from the impact and he fell to the ice.
"There's no place for it," Flyers coach Dave Hakstol said of Rinaldo's hit.
Rinaldo said he that had his "emotions going" in the game and that he thought he delivered a clean check. "It's unfortunate he's hurt. That's the last thing I want to do ... Especially someone that I know personally."
A few Flyers said it was a good thing Rinaldo was ejected because otherwise they may have been preoccupied trying to pay him back instead of playing their game.
As for Schenn, he was injured on a neutral-zone collision with Dallas' Antoine Roussel on Tuesday, and he sat out the stirring 5-4 comeback win over Boston in overtime one night later.
If Schenn and Couturier can't play Saturday, Vinny Lecavalier (remember him?) figures to make his first appearance of the season.
Backup goalie Michal Neuvirth was also injured against Boston and was removed after the first period. While Patrice Bergeron scored a goal, his stick inadvertently hit Neuvirth in the mask. Neuvirth is also listed as day-to-day.
It was 2-2 at the time of Rinaldo's hit, just before the first period ended. Boston later built a 4-2 lead before third-period goals by Claude Giroux and Wayne Simmonds tied it.
Giroux won it with 2:51 left in overtime, firing a one-timer from the left circle past Tuukka Rask while the Flyers were on a four-on-three power play. It was Giroux's sixth career OT goal, tying him with Simon Gagne for the most in franchise history, according to the Elias Sports Bureau.
In the first period, Giroux made two mistakes (an errant pass and a four-minute high-sticking penalty) that led to Boston's first two goals, but he redeemed himself late in the game.
Giroux finished with two goals, five shots, four hits, and wins in 14 of 23 faceoffs (61 percent). He was an impressive 10 for 19 (53 percent) against Bergeron, who has won 58.4 percent of his career faceoffs.
The Flyers outhit the Bruins, 38-28. Michael Raffl had seven of the hits.
"We played a light game," Boston coach Claude Julien said. "A lot lighter than them. They certainly were better in the battles than we were. ... We had too many guys with light sticks."
